titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Slam Stewart Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Emily DiLeo, Mary Jones and David Metzer

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 00:32

did.abstract: The Papers document the latter part of Slam Stewart's career, during his appointment at SUNY Binghamton. Stewart gave many concerts and lectures during this time – locally, nationally and internationally. He also played in many jazz festivals. The collection includes photographs, music, correspondence, and sound recordings from this time, and highlights the collegial nature of Stewart's career. Fellow musicians such as Peter Appleyard, Jack Martin (a.k.a., "Ludwig Sigmund von Christ"), Bucky Pizzarelli, Benny Goodman, Slim Gaillard, Major "Mule" Holley, Carrie Smith and Dick Hyman (among many others) appear in several series in the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Papers document the latter part of Slam Stewart's career, during his appointment at SUNY Binghamton. Stewart gave many concerts and lectures during this time – locally, nationally and internationally. He also played in many jazz festivals. The collection includes photographs, music, correspondence, and sound recordings from this time, and highlights the collegial nature of Stewart's career. Fellow musicians such as Peter Appleyard, Jack Martin (a.k.a., "Ludwig Sigmund von Christ"), Bucky Pizzarelli, Benny Goodman, Slim Gaillard, Major "Mule" Holley, Carrie Smith and Dick Hyman (among many others) appear in several series in the collection.

The Music series contains jazz band and combo arrangements – many of which are jazz standards. The 200 sound recordings are mostly dubs of commercial recordings (some of which may be rare), but also contain some unique material. Photographs include portraits of Slam Stewart, as well as Stewart with friends and family. Programs, clippings and publicity document Stewart's appearances at festivals and various concert series in the U.S. and abroad.

The Playlists (set lists) indicate the order of songs played at live shows in which Slam Stewart played, and the tour schedules outline Stewart's performances in the later part of his life. Correspondence includes letters from colleagues, friends and fans. The collection also includes some contracts and awards.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Music Library files indicate that photographs from this collection may have been moved into the Stanley Dance Papers (MSS 62).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Researchers may wish to consult the Stanley Dance Papers (MSS 62), the Benny Goodman Papers (MSS 53), and the Red Norvo Papers (MSS 48), all held by the Gilmore Music Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Leroy Elliott "Slam" Stewart was one of the pre-eminent double-bass players in American jazz. Born in Englewood, New Jersey on 21 September 1914, Stewart originally studied the violin but soon switched over to the bass. During his years at the Boston Conservatory of Music, he developed his signature technique of bowing and humming a melody simultaneously at the interval of an octave. In 1935, he began a successful partnership with the guitarist Slim Gaillard – the duo called themselves "Slim and Slam." Their song, "Flat Foot Floogie," became very popular. In 1941, Stewart joined Art Tatum's trio, with which he appeared intermittently until Tatum's death in 1956. He also formed his own ensembles on 52nd or "Swing" Street, with the pianists Billy Taylor, Erroll Garner, and Johnny Guarnieri. Stewart appeared in several Hollywood films, including "Hellzapoppin" (1941) and "Stormy Weather" (1943). He also played with Benny Goodman's Sextet and Big Band, from 1945 to 1947. During the 1950s, Stewart performed with Roy Eldridge's Quartet and the pianist and singer Rose Murphy. Stewart also played with some of the leading Bop musicians, notably Dizzy Gillespie and Charlie Parker.

In 1971, SUNY Binghamton invited Stewart to join the music faculty. During this time, Stewart toured extensively, appearing with the Goodman Sextet, Bucky Pizzarelli, and the Newport Jazz Festival All-Stars, among others. Stewart also turned his attention to Baroque and Classical repertoires, assisted by the Lincoln and Lenox Quartets and the harpsichordists Christine Lindsay and Frances Cole. Stewart received many awards, as well as a Grammy nomination. In 1984, SUNY Binghamton awarded him an honorary doctorate. Stewart died in Binghamton on 10 December 1987.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Leroy Elliot ("Slam") and Claire Stewart.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: MSS 59, the Slam Stewart Papers in the Gilmore Music Library at Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Slam Stewart Papers contain 11 series: I. Music; II. Sound Recordings; III. Photographs; IV. Programs; V. Clippings, publicity, and posters; VI. Playlists; VII. Tour schedules; VIII. Writings and correspondence; IX. Contracts and financial materials; X. Awards; and XI. Miscellaneous.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Music is organized alphabetically by title, with the composer's name in parentheses. If an arranger's name is present on the document, his/her name likewise appears in parentheses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains jazz band and combo arrangements. Some of the arrangements contain scores and/or parts - others have only a bass part. Most of the arrangements are jazz standards. Also included are a few compositions/arrangements by Slam Stewart.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Slam Stewart Papers contain roughly 200 sound recordings – mostly cassette tapes, and a few reel-to-reel tapes. Artists who appear on these recordings include Erroll Garner, Slim Gaillard, Red Norvo, Bucky Pizzarelli, Benny Goodman, Ludek Hulan, Rose Murphy, Al Hamme, Major ("Mule") Holley, Carrie Smith, Dick Hyman and Louie Bellson. A handful of tapes are most certainly unique, for example, Slam and Bucky Pizzarelli chatting, and a rendition of "Potty", a tune that commemorates the bathroom in Stewart's house in Binghamton, upon whose walls his friends wrote their signatures. Other content includes interviews, radio broadcasts (in particular, memorials for Slam Stewart), and some live shows in which Stewart played. The vast majority of the tapes, however, are dubs of other (likely commercial) recordings. They appear to be mix tapes made for Stewart by his friends and colleagues. Among these, probably the most notable are dubs of commercial European discs from the 1940s, sent to Stewart by people he met while touring there. Note that many of these original recordings can be found in Historical Sound Recordings, including labels such as Black and Blue (France) and Savoy Records (U.S.). There are two videotapes in this series, which contain the following programs: Security Mutual Concert (Binghamton, NY) 1986; Artscene Interview with Slam Stewart 1983; Action News featuring Claire Stewart (Binghamton, NY) 1988; Tribute concert for Slam Stewart 1988; Benny Goodman Let's Dance [tribute concert] 1986; The Best of Everything - Frank Sinatra [Slam Stewart is mentioned in the beginning of the program].

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The videotapes have been digitized. Please contact Special Collections staff for access.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Photographs are organized by subject and number of people: "Slam Stewart Alone," "Slam Stewart with one person," etc.). In the subseries "Slam Stewart Alone," black and white and color photographs are separated. When possible, the names of additional people are indicated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs include portraits of Slam Stewart, as well as Stewart with friends and family. This series contains two photo albums.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains programs in which Slam Stewart appeared, including festivals in the U.S. and abroad.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is divided into three subseries: Clippings, Publicity, and Posters. Each subseries is organized chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains newspaper clippings about Slam Stewart from around the U.S., including the Philadelphia Daily News, Indianapolis Star, San Francisco Chronicle, New York Times, Chicago Sun Times, and various local papers in Binghamton, NY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes press releases, newsletters, posters, flyers and arts calendars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries contains several concert posters - two are autographed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The playlists (set lists) indicate the order of songs played at live shows in which Slam Stewart played. The playlists are undated and do not indicate venue. A couple of the playlists include commentary about the songs themselves, and Stewart also wrote down exactly what he was to say between tunes. Also included is a playlist that outlines Stewart's presentation to school children about the origins and history of jazz.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, lectures, biographies and discographies. Correspondence includes letters from colleagues, friends and fans, including Beryl Booker, Marian McPartland, and Ronald Reagan.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is divided into four subseries, including Correspondence, Lectures, Biographies and Discographies, and Writings by Others. The correspondence is organized chronologically, while each of the other subseries is organized by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jazz History Lecture, SUNY Binghampton, 1971; "Swing Era" Talk; Motivational Speech

did.unittitle: Biographical Portrait by Monday Date Jazz Circle Zurich

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Details of Slam's life in Binghampton c. 1968 (stories)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains American Federation of Musicians contracts for various gigs. Financial materials include a work visa for the U.K., tax documents, and handwritten expense records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains honorary doctorates and awards from institutions such as the Sertoma Club, the American Legion, the National Academy of Recordings Arts and Sciences, and the Jazz Musicians' Foundation. Includes papers awards and wooden plaques.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Amateur drawings, comic strips and an informational brochure for oil portrait of Slam Stewart (portrait is housed in the Music Library). Also included are several prints signed "Pezuce Bates".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Various arts institutions' reports, record catalogs, and a calendar in which Stewart appears. Signed record jacket.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two large, folding wooden music stands. Painted red and white with "Slam Stewart" on the front.
